title: Quiz 1: Introduction & Glossary
topicName: Cardiology Cardiac Electrophysiology  A Visual Guide for Nurses
description: Assessment on introductory electrophysiology concepts, standard abbreviations, and key definitions.

questions.question: Match the standard Electrophysiology abbreviation to its correct anatomical definition.
questions.explanation: Standard EP abbreviations: CS (Coronary Sinus) is the vein draining the heart; HRA (High Right Atrium) is near the sinus node; RVA (Right Ventricular Apex) is the tip of the RV; CTI (Cavo-Tricuspid Isthmus) is the target for flutter ablation.
questions.hint: Think about the anatomical location associated with each letter.

questions.question: What is the definition of 'Antidromic' in the context of Atrioventricular Reentrant Tachycardia (AVRT)?

options.text: Conduction down the accessory pathway and up the AV node
Conduction down the AV node and up the accessory pathway
Conduction going in the same direction as the predominant wave
Conduction that blocks in both directions simultaneously

questions.explanation: Antidromic means 'against the current'. In AVRT, it refers to the circuit going down the accessory pathway (causing a wide QRS due to pre-excitation) and up the AV node, which is opposite to the normal physiological conduction direction.
questions.hint: Does this conduction direction result in a narrow or wide QRS complex?

questions.question: An 'Echo' beat in an EP study is defined as an unexpected return of a wave of depolarization to the chamber where the wave originated.
questions.explanation: True. An echo beat is essentially a single beat of reentrant tachycardia returning to its origin (e.g., an atrial beat traveling down the AV node and returning to the atrium).
questions.hint: Think of how sound returns to its source.

questions.question: The pacing interval at which 1:1 conduction is lost (block occurs) is known as the ___BLANK___ cycle length.
questions.explanation: The Wenckebach cycle length is the pacing interval (shortest cycle length) where the AV node (or other tissue) can no longer conduct every beat 1:1, usually displaying progressive delay before the block.
questions.hint: Named after a famous cardiologist describing progressive block.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes a 'Concealed' accessory pathway?

richContent.content: Clinical Scenario: A patient presents with SVT (narrow complex). During Sinus Rhythm, their 12-lead ECG appears completely normal with a normal PR interval and no delta wave.

options.text: It conducts retrogradely only (V to A) and shows no delta wave
It is located deep within the septum
It conducts antegradely only (A to V)
It has very slow decremental conduction properties

questions.explanation: A concealed pathway conducts only from ventricle to atrium. Since it doesn't conduct antegradely, there is no pre-excitation (delta wave) on the surface ECG during sinus rhythm, effectively 'concealing' its presence until tachycardia starts.
questions.hint: If it doesn't show up on the ECG during sinus rhythm, why is that?
